# HRI 2026: Call for Papers

The ACM/IEEE International Conference on Human-Robot Interaction (HRI) is the premier, highly-selective venue presenting the latest advances in Human-Robot Interaction. The 21st edition of HRI, themed **"HRI Empowering Society"**, will be held from **March 16–19, 2026**.

HRI brings together researchers spanning robotics, human-computer interaction, human factors, artificial intelligence, engineering, and social and behavioral sciences.

## Submission Types

*   **Full Papers**
*   **Workshop Proposals** (Tentative: October 2025)
*   **Late-Breaking Reports** (Tentative: December 2025)

## Full Papers

The conference seeks contributions from a broad set of perspectives, including technical, design, behavioral, theoretical, and methodological, that advance fundamental and applied research in human-robot interaction. Full papers will be archived in the ACM Digital Library.

### Important Dates

| Submission Type             | Deadline                        |
| :-------------------------- | :------------------------------ |
| Abstract Submissions        | September 22nd, 2025            |
| Full Paper Submissions      | September 30th, 2025            |
| Review Notification         | November 10th, 2025 (Tentative) |
| Rebuttals Due               | November 14th, 2025             |
| Decision Notification       | December 1st, 2025              |
| Camera Ready Deadline       | January 9th, 2026               |

### Abstract Submission

*   All full papers **must** submit an abstract and basic details about the paper a week before the paper submission deadline. Papers that did not submit the abstract on time will not be accepted.
*   The abstract, title, and author information submitted at the abstract deadline must be complete. Submissions with placeholder or incomplete information will be deleted.

### Format and Submission

*   **Length:** Full papers are up to **eight (8) camera-ready pages**, including figures, but **excluding references**. Submissions longer than eight pages of content (excluding references) will be desk-rejected.
*   **Review Model:** HRI has a rigorous, **two-stage review model** with expert program committee discussion.
*   **Format:** All papers must be submitted in **PDF format** and conform to IEEE Proceedings specifications.
*   **Templates:** Templates are available via [IEEE Proceedings specifications](https://humanrobotinteraction.org/2026/full-papers/) and [Overleaf](https://www.overleaf.com/latex/templates/ieee-conference-proceedings-template/yrsqvztpwvwx).

### Tracks

Authors must choose a track (and optionally a second choice) during abstract submission. The Program Committee may suggest a track change.

1.  **Theory and Methods:** Focuses on conceptual foundations, new ways of thinking about HRI, and advancing research methodologies. Contributions may include meta-analyses, theoretical arguments, new interpretations of results, or novel evaluation methodologies. Theory papers are not expected to have user studies. Methods for generating design belong in the Design track; methods for measuring or studying HRI belong in Theory and Methods.
2.  **Design:** Focuses on design-centric research, including novel design approaches, robot morphologies, behavior paradigms, interaction techniques, and contexts. This track welcomes papers on design solutions with rigorous detail, design-driven methodologies, and the design process itself. Evaluations are typically end-user evaluations or critical reflections on the design process.
3.  **Technical:** Primary contribution is a novel algorithm, mathematical model, tool, hardware element, or human-robot interface, with sufficient detail for reproducibility. Rigor, robustness, and appropriate evaluations (which may include user studies if appropriate, but not required) are expected. Papers may include proofs of correctness, demonstrations, simulations, or technical performance evaluations. A "pathway to deployment" description is required if no physical robot demonstration is included.
4.  **Systems:** Focuses on contributions that synthesize underlying techniques and/or technologies to achieve system-level HRI behavior. The contribution is best observed through the performance of an integrated system. This can involve novel system design or integration of novel techniques/components. Authors should emphasize novelty, significance, and wider systems knowledge applicable to future HRI problems.
5.  **User Studies:** Welcomes submissions providing new knowledge about human-robot interactions based on studies involving people (laboratory or field studies, ethnographic work, replication studies, industry case studies). Studies may involve autonomous robots, Wizard of Oz methods, or no physical robot. The primary knowledge contribution is expected to be from the study itself.

#### Subthemes (for User Studies Track)

*   **Interpersonal Constructs:** Emotional, social, behavioral, and interpersonal aspects of HRI.
*   **Special Populations:** Robots supporting learning, therapy, care, or personal growth across the lifespan.
*   **Teams, Collaboration & Communication:** Task-based interaction and teamwork with robots.
*   **None:** If no subtheme is appropriate.

## ACM Open Access Publishing Model

*   Starting January 1, 2026, all ACM publications will be 100% Open Access.
*   Authors can publish via the **ACM Open institutional model** (supported by over 1,800 institutions, meaning most papers won't require APCs) or by paying **Article Processing Charges (APCs)**.
*   **Temporary Subsidy for 2026:** To ease the transition, ACM offers a subsidized APC: **$250 for ACM/SIG members** and **$350 for non-members**.
*   Authors are encouraged to advocate for their institutions to join ACM Open.

## ACM Publication Policies

Authors must adhere to all ACM Publications Policies, including the **new Publications Policy on Research Involving Human Participants and Subjects** and the **ACM Policy on Authorship**.

## Accessibility

Accessibility requirements will be provided soon.

## Anonymization

*   The HRI 2026 review process is **double-blind**. All aspects of submissions must be properly anonymized.
*   Violations will result in desk rejection. Contact Program Chairs for exceptional circumstances.
*   See [anonymization guidelines](https://humanrobotinteraction.org/2025/anonymization/) (coming soon).

## Supplementary Materials

Authors may upload up to three supplemental files (videos, appendices, artifacts). These materials must also be properly anonymized.

*   **Video Guidelines:** 1-minute video (up to 100 MB), MPG, MPEG, or MP4 formats. Videos may be used for Demo Fast Track consideration.
*   **Artifact Guidelines:** Encourages novel artifacts (software, hardware, data sets, etc.) for reproducibility. Include a detailed description, novelty information, anonymized link, and a clearance file.
*   **Appendix Guidelines:** For supplementary materials that would interrupt the text flow. Cannot be used to circumvent page limits. Appended material must not contain new experimental analysis or results.

## Studies with Human Participants

*   Submissions involving human participants must clearly outline their methodology (participant demographics, data collection/analysis, study environment, robot/wizard description if applicable).
*   **Ethical Approval Statement:** A statement of IRB/ethics committee approval is required. If no approval was obtained, an explanation of compliance with ethical principles must be provided. Consent from legal carers/parents is required for child users, along with oral assent from minors.

## Policy on Use of ChatGPT or Similar Models

*   Text, images, or material generated from foundation models (LLMs, VLMs) must be **clearly marked** if used for purposes beyond editing author's text.
*   AI systems do not satisfy authorship criteria and cannot be used as citable sources.
*   Authors are responsible for content, plagiarism, and veracity.

## Desk Rejects

Reasons for desk rejection include:

*   Scope: Clearly out of scope for the conference.
*   Anonymization: Violation of anonymization guidelines.
*   Incomplete Submissions: Missing information (e.g., placeholder title/abstract).
*   Formatting Issues: Exceeding page limit, incorrect format.
*   Other: Unfinished paper, obvious LLM-generated content, not in English.

## Contact

Program Chairs: Maartje de Graaf, Matthew Gombolay, Ilaria Torre.

Email: [pc2026@humanrobotinteraction.org](mailto:pc2026@humanrobotinteraction.org)

# CICM 2025: Call for Papers

The 18th Conference on Intelligent Computer Mathematics (CICM 2025) will be held from **October 6 – 11, 2025**, in **Brasilia, Brazil**.

More and more mathematical information is digitally processed, generated, communicated, stored, and curated. CICM brings together the many separate communities that have developed theoretical and practical solutions for mathematical applications such as computation, deduction, knowledge management, and user interfaces. It offers a venue for discussing problems and solutions in each of these areas and their integration.

Besides the CICM main program soliciting formal CICM submissions there will be associated workshops with separate submission options.

## Topics of Interest

We are inviting formal submissions on all topics relating to intelligent computer mathematics, in particular, but not limited to:

*   theorem proving and computer algebra
*   mathematical knowledge management
*   digital mathematical libraries

A comprehensive but not exhaustive list of topics of interest can be found on the conference website: [https://cicm-conference.org/2025/cicm.php?event=&menu=topics](https://cicm-conference.org/2025/cicm.php?event=&menu=topics)

## Formal Paper Submissions

Formal submissions in one of the following categories will be reviewed rigorously and accepted papers will be published in a volume of Springer LNAI:

*   **Regular papers:** (up to 15 pages + bibliography) present novel research results.
*   **Project and survey papers:** (up to 15 pages + bibliography) summarize existing results.
*   **System and dataset descriptions:** (4 to 5 pages + bibliography) present digital artifacts.

## Doctoral Symposium: Two-Page Abstracts

The doctoral program provides PhD students a forum to present early results to receive constructive feedback and mentoring. To attend, submissions of two-page abstracts are expected in which the focus and research questions of the expected PhD theses are described; details on completed research tasks and remaining research plans should be given. In addition to these abstracts, a two-page CV of the applicant should also be submitted, detailing background information (name, university, supervisor), education (sought degree, previous degrees), employments and relevant research experience (publications, attended conferences/workshops).

*   Theoretical contributions on digital play and games
*   Accessible and inclusive design of player-computer interactions
*   Esports, live streaming, and spectator experiences
*   Advances in digital game user research, game evaluation methods, and methods for conducting games research
*   Psychology and typologies of digital games and players
*   Applied, serious, and persuasive digital games (e.g., games and play for health, well-being, and learning)
*   Gamification and motivational design
*   Virtual and augmented reality in games and play
*   New tools for digital game creation and co-creation affecting player experience and/or player-computer interactions
*   Game analytics and novel visualizations of player-computer interactions
*   Developer experiences and studies of developers of digital games
*   Applications of human-centered game AI with implications for HCI games research
*   Critical and reflexive approaches to digital games & play design and experience
*   Gaming industry case studies

Technical contributions without impact on players or other relevant people in the game community, nor systems without a gameful or playful component, nor physical games without a digital element and/or core contribution to player-computer interaction are generally out of scope.

Translations of articles published in other languages are welcome, provided the original authors remain and the paper is clearly identified as a translation.

## Submission Process Details

*   PACMHCI GAMES uses the Precision Conference System (PCS) 2.0: [https://new.precisionconference.com/submissions](https://new.precisionconference.com/submissions). Select “SIGCHI” as the Society and “CHI PLAY” as the Conference/Journal.
*   Authors must comply with the [ACM Policy on Authorship](https://www.acm.org/publications/policies/new-acm-policy-on-authorship).
*   Confidentiality of submitted material will be maintained.
*   Authors must ensure they and their co-authors have an ORCID ID.
*   Submissions must be anonymized (names, affiliations, and identifying statements removed).

## Formatting and Length

*   PACMHCI GAMES uses ACM Journals Primary Article Template, available for [LaTeX (and Overleaf)](https://dl.acm.org/journal/pacmhci/submission-templates) and [Word](https://dl.acm.org/journal/pacmhci/submission-templates).
*   No minimum or maximum page length is imposed, but reviewers will weigh the contribution relative to its length. Typical papers are under 10,000 words (approx. 17-20 pages single column).

## Anonymous Review Policy

Submissions must have authors’ names and affiliations removed, and avoid obvious identifying statements. Citations to authors’ own relevant work should be done without identifying the authors (e.g., “Prior work by [authors]” instead of “In our prior work.”).

## Revision Cycles and Decisions

*   **Accept with Minor Revisions:** Requires small changes. Final version due within 6 weeks.
*   **Revise and Resubmit:** Potential for acceptance but requires major revisions and re-review. Revised manuscript due at revision deadline.
*   **Reject:** Not acceptable in current form and unlikely to be improved within the revision period.
*   **Desk Reject:** For incomplete, non-anonymized, concurrent submissions, plagiarism, wrong format, poor quality, out-of-scope, or insufficient contribution.

## Contribution Type for Review Handling

Authors should indicate the primary and secondary contribution type for reviewer assignment (e.g., Empirical-Qualitative, Artefact-Technical, Theoretical).

## Open and Transparent Science

Authors are encouraged to submit supplementary material (e.g., interview guides, videos) and links to pre-registrations on the Open Science Framework (OSF) when appropriate.

## ACM Policy on Use of Generative AI

Generative AI tools are permitted but must be disclosed, and authors are responsible for the content and any plagiarism. The AI tool cannot be listed as an author.

## ACM Publications Policy

All authors must comply with ACM Publications Policies, including those regarding research involving human participants and subjects.

## Video Figures

Video figures are mandatory for submissions featuring custom-built games or systems not freely available. Videos should showcase the work comprehensively and be no more than three minutes long.

## Presenting at the CHI PLAY Conference

Accepted papers are invited to present at the ACM CHI PLAY conference (Oct 13–16, 2025). Presentation is strongly recommended but not required for publication.

## Important Dates

*   **Submission deadline:** February 19, 2025
*   **Notifications:** April 14, 2025 (Accept with Minor Revisions/Revise and Resubmit/Reject)
*   **Revisions due:** June 2, 2025
*   **Final notifications:** July 4, 2025

# ASPLOS 2025: Call for Papers

ASPLOS 2025, the ACM International Conference on Architectural Support for Programming Languages and Operating Systems, will be held in **Rotterdam, The Netherlands**, from **March 30 to April 3, 2025**. The conference is co-located with **EuroSys 2025**, and a single registration fee provides access to both conferences.

ASPLOS is the premier academic forum for multidisciplinary applied computer systems research, spanning hardware, software, and their interaction. It focuses on practical aspects of computer architecture, programming languages, operating systems, and closely-related areas such as networking and storage.

## Key Changes for ASPLOS 2025:

*   **Two submission cycles:** Spring and Summer, encouraging authors to submit when ready.
*   **Limit on author submissions:** To ensure broader participation.
*   **Explicit assessment of Interdisciplinary research:** To encourage cross-disciplinary contributions.
*   **Unlimited appendix:** For supplementary material.

## Program Chairs

*   Benjamin C. Lee, University of Pennsylvania
*   Harry Xu, University of California Los Angeles
*   Mark Silberstein, Technion – Israel Institute of Technology

## Important Dates

### Spring Cycle

*   Abstract submission: **March 05, 2025** (11:59pm Eastern)
*   Full paper submission: **March 12, 2025**
*   Author response: June 09 — 13, 2025
*   Notification: June 24, 2025

### Summer Cycle

*   Abstract submission: **August 13, 2025** (11:59pm Eastern)
*   Full paper submission: **August 20, 2025**
*   Author response: November 10 — 14, 2025
*   Notification: November 24, 2025

## Submission Website

*   [Spring Cycle HotCRP](https://asplos26-spring.hotcrp.com/)

## Scope and Expectations

ASPLOS covers all practical aspects related to computer architecture, programming languages, and operating systems, including but not limited to:

*   Operating systems, file and storage systems, distributed systems, cloud computing, mobile and edge systems.
*   Secure and reliable systems, systems aspects of big data and machine learning, embedded and real-time systems, and virtualization.

We seek original, high-quality research submissions that improve and further the knowledge of applied computer systems, with emphasis on the intersection between the main ASPLOS disciplines.

Research may target diverse goals such as throughput, latency, energy, and security. Non-traditional topics are encouraged, and the review process will be sensitive to the challenges of multidisciplinary work in emerging areas. Submissions with accompanying artifacts (traces, source code, tools) are highly valued.

### Areas of Interest:

*   Existing, emerging, and nontraditional compute platforms at all scales
*   Heterogeneous architectures and accelerators
*   Internet services, cloud computing, and datacenters
*   Memory, storage, networking, and I/O
*   Power, energy, and thermal management
*   Profiling, debugging, and testing
*   Security, reliability, and availability
*   Systems for enabling parallelism and computation on big data
*   Virtualization and virtualized systems

## Interdisciplinary Research Assessment

The interdisciplinary nature of a paper will be a significant factor in acceptance. Authors will be asked to identify and justify the core disciplines their paper contributes to. Papers with a single specified discipline are less likely to be accepted.

## Resubmissions

Authors resubmitting work must describe changes in a separate note. Papers rejected from ASPLOS cycles cannot be resubmitted to the immediately subsequent two cycles.

## Limit on Submissions

Authors are limited to 5 submissions per submission cycle.

## Major Revisions

Some submissions may receive a "Major Revision" decision, allowing authors to resubmit after addressing specific reviewer feedback. Revised submissions can have up to 13 pages.

## Anonymization

ASPLOS employs a double-blind review process. Authors must anonymize their submissions by avoiding self-identification or institutional affiliation in submitted documents, including metadata. References to one's own work should be anonymized.

## Supplemental Material and Appendixes

Supplemental material and appendixes may be submitted with no page limit, but reviewers are not required to read them.

## Declaring Conflicts of Interest

Authors must register all conflicts (people and institutions) in their HotCRP submission page. Failure to declare conflicts may lead to summary rejection.

## Originality and Concurrent Submissions

Manuscripts must be original and not under review elsewhere. Posting on public repositories like arxiv.org is not considered prior publication. Violation of these conditions will lead to rejection.

## Ethical Obligations

Authors must not break anonymity, contact reviewers inappropriately, or advertise their work during specific periods. Adherence to ACM ethics policies is required.

## Formatting and Editing

*   **File format:** PDF with numbered pages.
*   **Page limit:** 11 pages (excluding references and appendices).
*   **Paper size:** US Letter (8.5in x 11in).
*   **Margins:** 1 inch top/bottom, 0.75 inch left/right.
*   **Body:** 2-column, single-spaced, 10pt font.
*   **Template:** Use the ACM SIGPLAN acmart Latex class (`sigplan` option, `nonacm` option).
*   **Figures/Tables:** Fonts within figures and tables should be legible (preferably >= 9pt).
*   **References:** List full author names, include clickable links (preferably DOIs), and ensure hyperlinked citations.

Submissions violating formatting restrictions may be rejected without review.

## Author Response Period

Authors will have an opportunity to respond to reviews. Rebuttals should focus on correcting factual errors and addressing reviewer questions. They can optionally include new experiments if relevant.

## Accepted Papers

Accepted papers are allowed extra pages for the camera-ready version. At least one author is expected to attend and present the work. ORCID IDs are required for all authors.

## Artifact Evaluation

Artifact evaluation will continue for ASPLOS 2026.

## Poster and Lightning Sessions

Details on poster and lightning sessions will be available later.

## Wild and Crazy Ideas Session

A WACI session is tentatively planned.

## Best Paper Award

A selection of papers will receive a Best Paper Award.

## Program and Registration

Complete program and registration information will be available on the conference website.

## Confidentiality

All submissions will be treated as confidential.

## Contact

Please direct any questions to the program co-chairs at [asplos2026pcchairs@gmail.com](mailto:asplos2026pcchairs@gmail.com).

# CHES 2026: Call for Papers

## General Information

The **Workshop on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES) 2026** will take place in **Turkey** from **October 11-15, 2026**. CHES is the premier venue for research on both design and analysis of cryptographic hardware and software implementations, attracting participants from academia, industry, and government. The conference website is accessible at [https://ches.iacr.org/2026](https://ches.iacr.org/2026).

## Topics of Interest

Submissions are solicited on topics including, but not limited to:

### Cryptographic implementations:
*   Hardware architectures
*   Cryptographic processors and coprocessors
*   True and pseudorandom number generators
*   Physical unclonable functions (PUFs)
*   Efficient software implementation
*   SHARCS (Special-purpose HARdware for Cryptanalysis, quantum included)

### Attacks against implementations, and countermeasures:
*   Remote, micro-architectural and physical side-channel attacks and countermeasures
*   Fault attacks and countermeasures
*   Hardware tampering and tamper-resistance
*   White-box cryptography and code obfuscation
*   Reverse engineering of hardware/software
*   Hardware trojans and countermeasures

### Tools and methodologies:
*   Formal methods, techniques and tools for secure design and verification for hardware/software
*   Computer aided cryptographic engineering
*   Domain-specific languages for cryptographic systems
*   Metrics for the security of embedded systems
*   FPGA design security
*   Physical assurance and analysis of embedded systems
*   New datasets for public use
*   Systematization of Knowledge (SoK)

### Interactions between cryptographic theory and implementation issues:
*   Quantum cryptanalysis
*   Algorithm subversion and subversion prevention
*   New and emerging cryptographic algorithms and protocols targeting embedded devices
*   Theoretical hardware models that allow proofs

### Applications:
*   RISC-V security
*   Trusted execution environments and trusted computing platforms
*   IP protection for hardware/software and technologies for anti-counterfeiting
*   Reconfigurable hardware for cryptography
*   Secure elements, security subsystems, and applications
*   Security for the Internet of Things and cyberphysical systems (RFID, sensor networks, smart meters, medical implants, smart devices for home automation, industrial control, automotive, etc.)
*   Secure storage devices (memories, disks, etc.)
*   Isolation and monitoring hardware for cyberresilience
*   Engineering of zero-knowledge proof systems
*   Privacy-preserving computing in practice (MPC, FHE)
*   Post-quantum security

## TCHES Publication Model

CHES has transitioned to an open-access journal/conference hybrid model. Submitted papers undergo a journal-style review process, with accepted papers published by Ruhr University Bochum in an issue of the journal **IACR Transactions on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (TCHES)**. All papers published in TCHES are immediately and freely available due to its Gold Open Access status. The annual CHES conference consists of presentations for each paper published in the associated issues of TCHES, plus invited talks and additional activities. All papers accepted for publication in TCHES between July 15 of year n-1 and July 15 of year n will be presented at CHES of year n.

## Paper Submission

*   Author instructions for paper submission are on the [submissions page](papersubmission.php).
*   Submissions must be written in English and be anonymous, with no author names, affiliations, acknowledgments, or any identifying citations.
*   Papers should begin with a title, a short abstract, and a list of keywords.
*   Submissions should be typeset using the LaTeX style available at [https://tches.iacr.org/index.php/TCHES/submission](https://tches.iacr.org/index.php/TCHES/submission).
*   Only electronic submissions in PDF format are accepted.
*   Use the submission mode (`\documentclass[submission]{iacrtrans}`) that displays line numbers.
*   **Page Limit:** Up to 20 pages, including all figures, tables, and appendices, but excluding the bibliography. Appendices are reviewed.
*   **Long Papers:** Up to 40 pages, require pre-approval by the Editors-in-Chief at least one week before the submission deadline. The request must include the number of additional pages, justification, and a draft paper. Long papers must be marked as "Long Paper:" in the title and the justification included in supplementary material. Long papers submitted without pre-approval will be returned without review. Decisions for long papers may be deferred to a subsequent volume.
*   **SoK Papers:** Systematization of Knowledge papers are solicited. Authors should highlight these by annotating the title with "SoK:".
*   Submissions not meeting these guidelines risk rejection without consideration of their merits.

## Important Dates (Tentative)

All submission deadlines are at 23:59:59 Anywhere on Earth (AoE).

### Schedule for TCHES Volume 2026/1
*   **Submission:** 15 July 2025
*   **Rebuttal period:** 28–31 Aug. 2025
*   **Notification:** 15 Sept. 2025
*   **Camera ready:** 14 Oct. 2025

### Schedule for TCHES Volume 2026/2
*   **Submission:** 15 Oct. 2025
*   **Rebuttal period:** 27–30 Nov. 2025
*   **Notification:** 15 Dec. 2025
*   **Camera ready:** 14 Jan. 2026

### Schedule for TCHES Volume 2026/3
*   **Submission:** 15 Jan. 2026
*   **Rebuttal period:** 26 Feb.–1 Mar. 2026
*   **Notification:** 15 Mar. 2026
*   **Camera ready:** 14 April 2026

### Schedule for TCHES Volume 2026/4
*   **Submission:** 15 April 2026
*   **Rebuttal period:** 28–31 May 2026
*   **Notification:** 15 June 2026
*   **Camera ready:** 14 July 2026

## Review Process

*   Each paper will be double-blind reviewed by at least three members of the TCHES editorial board.
*   Authors are given the opportunity to submit a rebuttal after receiving reviews.
*   Decision types: outright accept, outright reject, minor revision (conditionally accepted, assigned shepherd), or major revision (invited to resubmit as a new paper).
*   Resubmission of previously rejected papers requires major modifications and pre-approval.

## Regulations

*   TCHES adheres to IACR policy regarding irregular submissions (e.g., parallel submissions), which will result in instant rejection.
*   TCHES follows IACR policy on conflicts of interest, requiring authors to disclose any circumstances that may create bias. A declaration regarding conflicts of interest and a guarantee to present if accepted are required at submission.
*   Authors are encouraged to check the TCHES FAQ: [https://tches.iacr.org/index.php/TCHES/faq](https://tches.iacr.org/index.php/TCHES/faq).

# IEEE International Symposium on Multimedia (ISM) 2025: Call for Papers

The 27th International Symposium on Multimedia (ISM 2025) will be held from **December 8-10, 2025**, at the **Roral Continental Hotel in Naples, Italy**. The conference will operate in a **hybrid format**.

ISM 2025 is co-located with RoboticCC 2025 and AIxRobotics 2025.

## Topics of Interest

Research in multimedia computing is concerned with the presentation, integration, and computation of one or more media (text, image, graphics, audio, video, social data, sensor data, etc.) using computing techniques. Topics for submission include, but are not limited to:

### Systems and Architectures
*   Mobile multimedia systems and services
*   Pervasive and interactive media systems including mobile systems, pervasive gaming, and digital TV
*   Multimedia data in the Cloud
*   GPU-based multimedia architectures and systems
*   Software development framework using multimedia techniques

### Communications and Streaming
*   Multimedia networking and QoS
*   Mobile audio/video streaming
*   Wireless broadcasting and streaming
*   Scalable streaming
*   Peer-to-peer media systems and streaming
*   Sensor networks
*   Internet telephony technologies and systems
*   Video teleconferencing

### Multimedia Interfaces
*   Information visualization and interactive systems
*   Multimodal user interfaces: design, engineering, modality-abstractions, etc.
*   Tools for media authoring, analyzing, editing, browsing, and navigation
*   Intelligent agents for content creation, distribution, and analysis
*   Novel interfaces for multimedia: touch, tangible, wearable, virtual, 3D, etc.
*   User interfaces for mobile devices

### Media Coding, Processing, and Quality Measurement
*   Signal processing including audio, video, image processing, and coding
*   Coding standards
*   Scalable and Multi-view coding
*   Multi-resolution or super-resolution algorithms
*   Maintenance of perceptual quality with further compression
*   Developing novel quality measures

### Multimedia Security and Forensics
*   Data security including digital watermarks and encryption
*   Copyright issues for multimedia data
*   Surveillance and monitoring methods
*   Face detection and recognition algorithms
*   Human behavior analysis from motion images/videos
*   Multimedia-based computer forensics (e.g., crime scene investigation, user profiling)
*   Multimedia Captchas, including attacks and counter-attacks
*   On forensic use of biometrics
*   Data hiding, stenography, and steganalysis
*   Trust and privacy issues in media systems

### Content Understanding, Modeling, Management, and Retrieval
*   Media meta-modeling techniques
*   Storage systems, databases, and retrieval
*   Data segmentation
*   Image, audio, video, genre clustering & classification
*   Video summarization and story generation
*   Speaker identification, recognition, and location
*   Object, event, emotion, text detection and recognition
*   Mosaic, video panorama and background generation
*   Media semantics, ontologies, annotation, concept detection and learning
*   Personalization and user preferences
*   3D and depth information
*   Viewer perception, emotion analysis and visual attention
*   Multimedia datasets and open source code for research
*   Multimedia recommender systems
*   Fake multimedia detection

### Mobile Media
*   Mobile and location-based media techniques
*   Mobile visual search
*   Social networks for mobile users
*   Augmented reality for mobile users
*   Content delivery in mobile networks (e.g., 3G, 4G and future 5G)
*   Mobile applications

### Applications
*   Big data
*   3D data: graphics, displays, sound, broadcasting, interfaces
*   Media composition and production: capture, authoring, digital art, animations, etc.
*   Gaming
*   Virtual and augmented reality
*   Robotics
*   Media interfaces for the Web
*   Media in social network analysis
*   Rich media enabled E-commerce and E-shopping
*   Media systems for handicapped
*   Collaborative systems
*   Interdisciplinary media applications: Bioinformatics, Transportation systems, Wild-life monitoring and analysis, etc.
*   Deep learning of multimedia data

## Submission Types and Page Limits

*   **Full Papers:** 8 pages (up to 2 extra pages at $150 per extra page)
*   **Short Papers:** 4 pages (up to 1 extra page at $150 per extra page)
*   **Poster and Demo:** 2 pages

## Manuscript Preparation and Submission Instructions

*   Manuscripts must be written in English.
*   Submissions must be in **double-column IEEE format**.
*   Authors must follow the instructions in the [Manuscript Formatting and Templates page](https://www.multimediacomputing.org/submission).
*   Only electronic submission will be accepted.
*   Manuscripts may only be submitted in **PDF format**.
*   All paper submissions will be carefully reviewed by at least three experts.
*   Authors of accepted papers must guarantee that their paper will be presented at the conference.
*   Only original material where copyright of all parts is owned by the authors declared and which is not currently under review elsewhere should be submitted.
*   Refer to [IEEE policies](https://journals.ieeeauthorcenter.ieee.org/become-an-ieee-journal-author/publishing-ethics/guidelines-and-policies/submission-and-peer-review-policies/#:~:text=IEEE%20policy%20requires%20that%20authors,submissions%20when%20submitting%20an%20article.) for further information.

**Submission Portal:** [EasyChair](https://easychair.org/conferences?conf=ism2025)

## Camera-ready Submission Instructions

*   Final papers MUST be formatted to IEEE Computer Society Proceedings Manuscript Formatting Guidelines.
*   It is highly recommended that you proofread and check the layout of your paper BEFORE submitting.
*   Link for camera-ready submission: (TBA)
*   May only be submitted in PDF format.

## Important Notes

*   Every paper accepted for publication in the Proceedings MUST be presented during the conference.
*   Every accepted paper MUST have attached to it at least one registration at the full member/nonmember rate. For papers where all authors are students, one student author will be required to register at the full registration rate.
*   Failure to comply with these requirements will result in the removal of your paper from the conference proceedings.

## Important Dates

*   **Workshop Proposal:** August 1, 2025 PT
*   **Paper Submission:** September 1, 2025 PT
*   **Workshop Proposal Acceptance:** September 1, 2025 PT
*   **Notification of Paper Acceptance:** October 1, 2025 PT
*   **Workshop Paper Submission:** October 15, 2025 PT
*   **Camera Ready and Registration:** November 1, 2025 PT

## Registration Fees

No specific registration fee amounts are listed. However, it is mandatory that at least one author of each accepted paper registers at the full member/nonmember rate. If all authors are students, one student author must register at the full registration rate.

# ICCCI 2025: Call for Papers

The **17th International Conference on Computational Collective Intelligence (ICCCI 2025)** is an international scientific conference focused on research in computer-based methods of collective intelligence and their applications. It will be held on **12-15 November 2025** in **Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam**.

The conference aims to provide an internationally respected forum for scientific research in collective intelligence, covering topics such as collective processing, knowledge integration, data integration, group decision making, multi-criteria decision making, consensus computing, and social networks. Contributions from applied fields in industry and commerce are also welcome.

ICCCI 2025 is held exclusively on-site, and all accepted papers must be presented in person.

## Proceedings

The proceedings of ICCCI 2025 will be published by **Springer** in the series **Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence (LNCS/LNAI)** and **Communications in Computer and Information Science (CCIS)**. They will be distributed at the conference.

## Paper Preparation

*   **Language:** English
*   **Format:** Springer's LNCS/LNAI style
*   **Length:** 12-15 pages

## Paper Submission

*   Each paper should be submitted electronically as a single **PDF file** through EasyChair: [https://easychair.org/my/conference?conf=iccci20250](https://easychair.org/my/conference?conf=iccci20250)

## Other Requirements

*   **Originality:** All contributions should be original and not published elsewhere or intended to be published during the review period.
*   **Presentation:** All accepted papers must be presented by one of the authors, who must register for the conference and pay the fee. Only personally presented papers can be nominated for the Best Paper competition and considered for expanded publication in special journal issues.
*   **Plagiarism and Self-Plagiarism:** Authors are requested to avoid plagiarism and self-plagiarism. Springer uses iThenticate software to detect irregularities.
*   **Artificial Intelligence (AI)-Generated Text:** The publication of papers containing text generated by artificial intelligence (AI) is strictly prohibited. Submissions undergo a two-stage evaluation process where reviewers verify that papers are not AI-generated.

## Review Process

The review process is highly rigorous and comprises two phases:
1.  Initial assessments by International Program Committee members.
2.  Re-evaluation of submissions and reviews by the Meta-reviewing Committee.
Final decisions are made by the Program Committee.

## Important Dates

1.  **Special session proposals:** December 1, 2024
2.  **Special session acceptance:** December 7, 2024

4.  **Notification of acceptance:** June 2, 2025

*   **Organizational issues:** [iccci@pwr.edu.pl](mailto:iccci@pwr.edu.pl)

# ICAIL 2025: Call for Papers

The 20th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Law (ICAIL 2025) will be held in **Chicago at Northwestern University, June 16 to 20, 2025**.

ICAIL has been the foremost conference addressing research in Artificial Intelligence and Law since 1987. It is organized biennially by the International Association for Artificial Intelligence and Law (IAAIL), in cooperation with the ACM-SIGAI and Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI).

## Topics of Interest

We invite submissions of original papers on Artificial Intelligence & Law, covering foundations, methods, tools, systems, and applications. Topics may include, but are not limited to:

*   Argument mining on legal texts
*   Classification and automatic summarization of legal text
*   Computational methods for negotiation and contract formation
*   Computer-assisted dispute resolution
*   Computable representations of legal rules and domain specific languages for the law
*   Decision support systems in the legal domain
*   Deep learning on data and text from the legal domain
*   Dialog systems in the legal domain
*   e-discovery and e-disclosure
*   e-government, e-democracy, and e-justice
*   Empirical research (quantitative and qualitative analysis) on the use of AI systems in legal practice (for example in law courts, lawmaking, legal education, and legislative/normative or adjudicative activities in public administration)
*   Innovative applications in AI and Law
*   Philosophical and legal-theoretical analysis of the significance and implications of methodologies or technical features of AI systems (particularly in applications to Law) with respect to fundamental legal concepts and ethical issues.
*   Systems and methods designed for compliance checking with respect to normative principles, rules, and standards (legal or ethical)
*   Methodologies for the technical design in AI systems of compliance with normative principles, rules, and standards of trustworthy or responsible AI
*   Explainable AI for the legal domain
*   Formal and computational models of legal reasoning (e.g., argumentation, case-based reasoning), including deontic logics
*   Formal and conceptual modeling of fundamental legal concepts
*   Formal and computational models of evidential reasoning
*   Formal models of norms and norm-governed systems
*   Information extraction from legal databases and texts
*   Information retrieval, question answering, and literature recommendation in the legal domain
*   Intelligent legal tutoring systems
*   Intelligent support systems for forensics
*   Interdisciplinary applications of legal informatics methods and systems
*   Knowledge acquisition techniques for the legal domain, including related applications of natural language processing, argument, and data mining
*   Knowledge representation, knowledge engineering, and ontologies in the legal domain
*   Legal design involving AI techniques
*   Machine learning and data analytics applied to the legal domain
*   Natural language processing of legal text, including law-specific standard NLP tasks (e.g., Named Entity Recognition, Semantic Role Labeling, Translation, etc.)
*   Applications of generative AI systems (LLMs) to the legal domain in connection to machine learning systems or knowledge representation systems
*   Normative reasoning by autonomous agents
*   Open and linked data in the legal domain
*   Smart contracts and application of blockchain in the legal domain
*   Visualization techniques for legal information and data

## Submission Types

*   **Papers:** Present contributions from relevant topics. Long papers (up to 10 pages including references), short papers (up to 5 pages including references).
*   **Technology Demonstrations:** For creative, robust, and practical working applications and tools.
*   **Workshops and Tutorials:** Proposals for sessions on Monday, June 16th and Friday, June 20th.
*   **Doctoral Consortium:** For doctoral students describing their research/thesis.

## Paper Submissions

*   **Content Requirements:** Papers must make clear their relation to legal information, reasoning, or processes. They should include a statement about novel scientific contribution, well-developed relation to prior work, and a satisfying discussion of findings.
    *   Papers on generative AI, ML, or data mining should include sufficient depth in data, methodology, results, and analysis.
    *   Submissions focusing on reproduction, validation, constructive scrutinization, and extension of previously published works are encouraged.
    *   Formal or computational models should provide examples and/or reproducible simulations.
    *   Applications should describe motivations, techniques, implementation, and evaluation.
    *   All papers should discuss relevance to legal theory, practice, use of legal information, or impact on processes.
*   **Reproducibility:** It is highly recommended that code and data be published alongside the papers.
*   **Formatting:** Papers must be formatted using the ACM sigconf template (for LaTeX) or the interim template layout.docx (for Word). All papers should be converted to PDF.
*   **Submission Platform:** Submissions can be made via the conftool platform: [https://www.conftool.net/icail2025/](https://www.conftool.net/icail2025/)
*   **Reviewing:** Double-blind reviewing. Submitted papers must not include author names, affiliations, or acknowledgments. Identifying text should be removed or rephrased.
*   **Preprints:** Submitted papers may not be published as open access preprints before acceptance notifications. If submitted as preprints, they must be flagged.
*   **Contact for Questions:** [icail2025@conftool.net](mailto:icail2025@conftool.net)

## Workshop and Tutorial Proposals

*   **Topics:** Broad topics relevant to the AI and Law community.
*   **Requirements:** Title, summary of content, biography of presenter(s), significance, audience, publicity plans, format, length, organizers' details.
*   **Submission:** 2 to 4 pages via a filling form.
*   **Deadline:** December 20th, 2024.

## Demonstrations

A session for creative, robust, and practical working applications and tools.

*   **Submission:** A two-page extended abstract about the system (if not connected to a submitted paper). For demonstrations connected to a paper, email the Program Chair by the demo submission deadline.

## Doctoral Consortium

*   **Purpose:** To promote idea exchange among PhD researchers and provide feedback from leading scholars.
*   **Eligibility:** Current doctoral students with 8-12 months of work remaining, sole author submissions.
*   **Submission:** Up to 10 pages (English, LNCS format, PDF) jointly with a maximum 3-page CV. Submit to [https://www.conftool.net/icail2025/](https://www.conftool.net/icail2025/).
*   **Assessment:** By members from the AI and Law community.
*   **Publication:** Presenting authors may be invited to publish.
